Only in San Francisco - Lombard Street Which runs from east to west is world famous for a steep, one-block section with eight hairpin turns.
It runs From The Presidio east to The Embarcadero (with a gap on Telegraph Hill), most of the street's western segment is a major thoroughfare designated as part of U.S. Route 101.
Lombard Street or the spiral street is a one-block section, often referred to as "the crookedest street in the world", is located along the eastern segment in the Russian Hill neighbourhood.
A must for anyone visiting San Francisco.
It has embraced the Hilliness that has made SF famous in the movies with its steep streets and wonderful views.

This street has a famous one-block, zig-zag, twisted section with eight tight turns. The hill on which it is located has a slope of 27%. The street has a length of 180 metres (600 feet) long, and a straight-line drop of 125.7 metres (412.5 feet), Although Lombard, is not as steep as many other streets in the world, its zig-zagging brick road, and beautifully gardened slope make it a great tourist attraction.

The Guinness Book of Records lists Baldwin Street of Dunedin, New Zealand as the world’s steepest residential street. It has a vertical height of 47.22 metres, an average gradient of 3.41, and at its steepest point a gradient of 2.86, which translates to a slope of 35%.

Having been to both Lombard Street and Baldwin Street, I see Lombard as the greater tourist attraction, and much more exciting to drive down. Be prepared to wait in line to drive down Lombard Street. Typical wait time is 20 minutes, compared to no wait time for Baldwin Street.

Lombard Street is an east–west street in San Francisco, California that is famous for a steep, one-block section with eight hairpin turns. Stretching from The Presidio east to The Embarcadero (with a gap on Telegraph Hill), most of the street's western segment is a major thoroughfare designated as part of U.S. Route 101. The famous one-block section, claimed as "the crookedest street in the world", is located along the eastern segment in the Russian Hill neighborhood.
